reviewText: This is a wonderful little "Human Interest" story.  Well made.  Great little gem of a movie.  Way to go Fred!!
Title: Fred and Vinnie

reviewText: Odd couples can be great movie subjects, if handled in a creative and intelligent manner, and there are plenty films in Hollywood which explore these relationships. A recent successful effort in this risky field is the original and funny "Fred & Vinnie," helmed by first-time film director and veteran TV producer Steve Skrovan.The movie opens by telling us that "this is a pretty much true story," and we almost right away go to a hilarious scene in which Fred (Fred Stoller) is having a "romantic" dinner with a lady that tells him, "I hope no one sees me here with you. You drive like a pussy. Only a pussy signals when they are going to change lanes." Fred happens to be a lonely, struggling actor in Hollywood, whose closest friend, Vinnie (Angelo Tsarouchas), lives back east. Vinnie is overweight, and also happens to be a loner. They talk a lot by phone, and Vinnie enjoys listening to Fred real-life boring stories - he even records some of his phone messages. It is an amazing, yet weird friendship. One day, Vinnie decides to visit Fred in Hollywood, so that maybe he can find a job in show business. He arrives to Vinnie's apartment swearing that he was going to be "invisible" and that he was not going to be an inconvenience to Fred. Sadly, that is not the case, and Vinnie's daily habits slowly begin to annoy Fred, who lives a calm, structured life. Here, the movie moves to dark humor as these two fellows friendship is truly tested."Fred & Vinnie" will remind you about some friends that you have, and what you have to do to remain loyal and understanding. It really delves into the psychological and physical effects of relationships that are deteriorating, and it is based on the real-life friendship between Stoller and his late friend Vinnie D'Angelo (1947-2001). It's all about what true friendship means. At times, however, it reminded me of the Saturday Night Live segment "The Creature that wouldn't leave," with John Belushi. The DVD includes some of Vinnie's phone messages, Park City (Utah) interview, deleted scenes, and more. (USA, 2011, color, 89 min plus additional materials)Reviewed on January 29, 2013 by Eric Gonzalez for Horizon Movies
Title: Fred and Vinnie

reviewText: I've never watched a lot of TV programs, so I had no idea who Fred Stoller was going into this.  A little research yields that he was a guest star on "Everybody Loves Raymond" (his own physical resemblance to Ray Romano is startling) and was a writer for "Seinfeld".  That last explains a lot about the style of humor in "Fred & Vinnie".  Imagine a "Seinfeld" episode that turns a little dark and sad, and you'll get the idea.  If such an idea is not appealing to you, don't bother with this.This is, according to an opening title card, "pretty much a true story", not even bothering with changing the names of the guilty in the manner of a roman-a-clef.  As the details of Stoller's friend Vinnie D'Angelo get revealed, we can pretty much believe that it's mostly all true: this stuff, and this man Vinnie, are just too weird to make up.  Somehow along the path of his life, Stoller -- a stand-up comedian hustling his way through "guest appearances" on sitcoms in Hollywood -- befriended a cheerful agoraphobic living in Philadelphia named Vinnie.  Vinnie is about 400 pounds, has a pet parrot, reaches for the bowl of M&Ms; on first arising from bed, and will patiently sit and listen to all of your "weird stories", even if they're not particularly interesting or even "weird", really.  (Stoller's stories, usually involving bad dates or trips to the post office, would fit precisely into any "Seinfeld" episode, btw.)  Vinnie is, in short, a sort of ideal friend: far enough away to not incur obligations from you, and who finds you infinitely entertaining, laughing at all of your conversation, and even recording your phone calls on an infinite series of cassette tapes from his answering machine.  However, this movie poses a fascinating question: what if your ideal friend, who you know is a messed-up shut-in, decides to come visit and stay with you for a while?  Does the friend stay "ideal"?Answer: no.  I won't spoil the movie by belaboring the details, but I have to describe just one scene.  Things have gotten far along, and Stoller is desperate to get Vinnie out of his apartment.  One day as they're sitting in there, getting on each other's nerves, Stoller has problems locating his book-treatment in his computer files.  The director gives us a close-up of Stoller's face as he's seething in front of the machine.  Suddenly, behind him, we see a gigantic striped shirt that covers the whole of the background field behind Stoller.  We hear a hand rattling in a plastic bag and then the crunching of potato chips.  We see Stoller's dread, and we can also imagine it ourselves: a heavy, unhelpful presence behind us, hanging over us like a raincloud, no light visible, no way out.  Darkly funny, and all too real.  What a shot -- great work from the director there.Stoller successfully mines the humor and pathos from a real friendship in his life and gives us something that's pretty hard to forget.  I saw this film several days ago and it has stuck with me -- always a sign of a good film for me.  In particular, Angelo Tsourachas as Vinnie has stuck with me.  I was a little worried about him.  There's a scene where in a fit of pique he threatens to leave Stoller's place.  After about 20 seconds of packing up, he started sweating profusely.  This is not a good sign.  I hope Mr. Tsourachas has since lost a little weight after the release of this picture.  He's too good of an actor to lose, and I'd like to see more of his work.  My clearest visual imprint from "Fred and Vinnie" is Tsourachas, shot from the rear, sitting on Stoller's apartment roof, smoking cigarettes under the blazing L.A. sun, looking out at the view without a care in the world.  A nice life, if you can get it -- certainly not much sadder than his friend Stoller's life on the margins of the Hollywood factory, the depiction of which is another reason why I liked this movie.  The only false note is the whole business with Stoller's therapist.  Woody Allen killed the therapist angle as as trope, as far as I'm concerned, and I yawn every time I see therapy played for laughs in a movie.  Cut all that out, and write in more of the Fred/Vinnie dynamic, or even more scenes with the humorous gay couple who are Stoller's neighbors, and I'd give this 5 out of 5.  Still, I recommend checking it out.  I think you'll be surprised by how it sticks to you.
Title: Fred and Vinnie

reviewText: We couldn't get past the bad language in the first 10 minutes of the movie to actually review it. Very disappointing.
summary: This movie sounded like it would be a good comedy.
Title: Fred and Vinnie

reviewText: Stoller grates less than usual here---his sadsack shtick is good for a half hour sitcom episode and that's about it---but Vinnie more than makes up for it after awhile. We laughed a few times during the first act, then started to get rather tired of Vinnie's freeloading antics during the second act, and by an hour in we just didn't care anymore, and despite liking Vinnie as a character were finding nothing to laugh at any more. Life mirrors art! Which mirrors life in this true story, so good luck in that maze.Seeing as the pathos wears off pretty fast, all we were left with was the thought, "If this guy can't sell a few of his precious baseball cards to pay a little rent to the guys he sponges off 24/7/365, what kind of friend is he?"Perhaps to some Vinnie seems like a great friend, but in real life, I've known some Vinnies and they're not very funny or even fun after awhile. They get old fast, just like this Vinnie (the portrayal is perhaps far too accurate), and the jokes get painfully ironic very quickly, as here. The film is relatively well shot and the dialogue has moments, but it goes nowhere fast, just like guess who.If you know and love a Vinnie, you might like this, but if you don't, or do know and don't love a Vinnie, then you may find yourself watching this and wondering what many Vinnie hosts have asked themselves many times: "Why am I continuing to bother putting up with this?"And at 25 clams for a dvd with only a few not very interesting extras (the real life Vinnie's phone messages are not exactly hilarious), this is triple what it should cost. I'm guessing this won't be hitting blu-ray, especially as the dvd already costs more than hundreds of great films on BD. I'd buy all of those before recommending this.Nothing personal, Vinnie. Or Fred, who wrote this as a tribute and/or a cash-in on his pal's neuroses. But your problems aren't ours, and you're going to have to deal with them on your own from here on in.
summary: Starts out funny, gets boring and annoying just like Vinnie
Title: Fred and Vinnie

reviewText: Yuck?  It take too many frames for me to know this was not my kind of movie.  That's a wrap!
